metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (phenology camera observation data set of Sidaoqiao Superstation-2021）
metadata.description:
The dataset contains the phenological camera observation data of the Sidaoqiao Superstation in the downstream of Heihe integrated observatory network from May 2 to December 26, 2021. The instrument was developed and data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures data by look-downward with a resolution of 1280×720. For the calculation of the greenness index and phenology, the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)) needs to be calculated according to the region of interest, then the invalid value filling and filtering smoothing are performed, and finally the key phenological parameters are determined according to the growth curve fitting, such as the growth season start date, Peak, growth season end, etc. For coverage, first, select images with less intense illumination, then divide the image into vegetation and soil, calculate the proportion of vegetation pixels in each image in the calculation area. After the time series data is extracted, the original coverage data is smoothed and filtered according to the time window specified by the user, and the filtered result is the final time series coverage. This data set includes relative greenness index (Gcc).
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: How is 'relative greenness index' defined and calculated in vegetation monitoring?
Definition.Answer: The relative greenness index, or Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC), is defined as a measure of vegetation greenness. It is calculated using the formula GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, and B are the pixel values in the red, green, and blue channels of an image. This index helps in determining key phenological events by fitting growth curves.

Definition.Question: What are the typical components included in a dataset focused on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas?
Definition.Answer: A dataset on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange typically includes long-term fluxes such as energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. It may also include data from automatic weather stations, such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture profiles.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for plant phenology using phenocams compare to those used for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for plant phenology using phenocams involve capturing images with a specified frequency and analyzing them for relative greenness index, while energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert systems are collected using an eddy covariance system, scintillometer, and automatic weather stations to gather flux and meteorological data over time.

Interpretation.Question: How do the specific methodologies of data collection, such as the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, contribute to understanding the interactions between hydrometeorological factors and vegetation in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, which, along with hydrometeorological observations, provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This helps in recognizing the oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological and socioeconomic developments.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection and processing are posed by the ecological environment degradation in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas, and how do these challenges impact the interpretation of long-term datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, desertification, and dust storms complicate data collection and processing. These environmental issues can affect data quality and the ability to maintain long-term observations, impacting the interpretation of ecological dynamics and interactions in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Using phenology cameras with vertical downward data collection can improve the accuracy of growth season parameters by providing high-resolution images that facilitate the calculation of relative greenness indices, essential for determining key phenological phases like the start and end of the growing season in arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of integrating long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations from multiple stations on understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating long-term observations from multiple stations could enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions by providing comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of auxiliary hydrometeorological and soil data influence the interpretation of carbon balance in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of auxiliary hydrometeorological and soil data can significantly influence the interpretation of carbon balance by providing contextual information that helps in modeling and understanding the complex interactions between different ecosystem components, thereby offering insights into carbon sink dynamics in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to understand the characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems for sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of utilizing long-term observation datasets in artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to gain a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental techniques are used to obtain relative greenness indices from phenological camera data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The phenological camera used in arid and semi-arid regions employs a vertically downward data collection technique, capturing images with a resolution of 1280x720. For calculating relative greenness indices, the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC) is used, which is calculated as GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, and B are the red, green, and blue pixel values of the image. This process includes filling invalid values and smoothing, fitting growth curves to determine key phenological parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in the collection and processing of turbulent flux data in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Turbulent flux data in oasis–desert systems are collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly measurements. The procedure involves collecting auxiliary data, such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Data processing includes quality control measures and archiving, ensuring the reliability and accessibility of the datasets.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are images preprocessed to calculate vegetation cover from phenological camera data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To calculate vegetation cover, images are first preprocessed by selecting those with optimal lighting conditions that are not too bright. The images are then segmented into vegetation and soil components. The proportion of vegetation pixels in a specified area is calculated for each image, followed by smoothing the time series of vegetation cover data according to a user-specified time window.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the continuous observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The continuous observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems has been enabled by the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, along with automatic weather stations that record various hydrometeorological data.

Enablement.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the observation of oasis–desert ecosystems address the challenges posed by ecological environment degradation in arid and semiarid areas?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection methods, which include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, help address challenges by providing a comprehensive understanding of the ecological dynamics and interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do observations from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems enhance the understanding and sustainable management of these ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Observations from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems enhance understanding by providing detailed datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This data is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, which supports ecological stability and socioeconomic development, contributing to sustainable management efforts.

Expectation.Question: Why might long-term observational datasets be crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial because they provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is significant for recognizing the interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is essential to protect ecological stability and support socioeconomic development, helping to achieve goals like carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these regions.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise when collecting data on ecological environment degradation in arid inland river basins?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in collecting data on ecological environment degradation in arid inland river basins include dealing with crises such as drying up rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These conditions can make data collection difficult and affect the accuracy and reliability of the data obtained.

Expectation.Question: Why might using multiple data collection methods be beneficial for studying oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Using multiple data collection methods, such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, is beneficial because it allows researchers to gather comprehensive datasets that include energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters. This diverse range of data is necessary to thoroughly understand the complex interactions and dynamics within oasis–desert systems.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are current data collection methods in capturing the complex interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems for long-term ecological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, which include the use of eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, provide a comprehensive suite of observational datasets essential for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. These methods are effective in capturing the complex interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems and support long-term ecological studies.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges could arise in ensuring the accuracy and consistency of data collected from different stations in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in ensuring accuracy and consistency of data may include variations in local microclimates, equipment calibration and maintenance issues, data processing errors, and environmental factors such as dust storms or extreme weather events impacting data collection at different stations.

Assertion.Answer: The integration can be achieved by incorporating auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters alongside the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data collected through eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. This comprehensive dataset allows for a quantitative understanding of the interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems and supports ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from phenology cameras is processed to determine key phenological parameters like the start and end of the growing season.
Assertion.Answer: Data from phenology cameras is processed by calculating the relative green chromatic coordinate (GCC) and filling in invalid values before using filtering and smoothing techniques. The growth curve is then fitted to determine key phenological parameters such as the start, peak, and end of the growing season.

Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve using long-term observational datasets that include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Challenges in these methods include ecological environment degradation in inland river basins, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms.

Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures are divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, and hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations. These procedures ensure the accuracy and reliability of data used for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.
